Exempt  Firemen's  Association.  —  Organized 
1858.  Officers — President,  George  H.  Hosse- 
fross;  Vice  Presidents,  J.  L.  Van  Bokkelen  and 
George  W.  Gibbs;  Treasurer,  Clement  Fergu- 
son ;  Secretary,  Marcus  D.  Boruck. 

Independence  Fire  Company. — This  is  the 
name  of  a  new  independent  company  formed  by 
the  citizens  of  St.  Ann  Valley.  They  have  in 
use  a  small  New  York  side-stroke  engine.  The 
house  of  the  company  is  located  corner  Powell 
and  Eddy  streets.  Officers — President,  David 
Dwyer;  Foreman,  O.  B.  Oakley;  First  Assistant, 
Silas  M.  Locke ;  Second  Assistant,  Jas.  Peach  ; 
Secretary,  A.  J.  Moon ;  Treasurer,  N.  C.  Lane.

IT.  S.  Branch  Mint, 

North  side  of  Commercial  near  Montgomery. 

The  law  for  the  establishment  and  regulation 
of  the  United  States  Mint  and  the  branches 
thereof,  provides  that  any  person  may  deposit 
with  the  officers  in  charge  of  the  same,  gold  and 
silver  in  bullion,  grain  or  lumps,  which,  if  re- 
quested, shall  be  refined,  assayed  and  cast  into 
bars  or  coined  as  speedily  as  possible  after  the 
receipt  thereof,  the  bars  to  be  stamped  in  said 
mint  or  branches,  in  such  manner  as  shall  indi- 
cate the  fineness  and  value  of  the  same  ;  the  ex- 
pense incurred  to  be  retained  from  each  deposit 
so  made,  at  such  rates  and  charges  and  under 
such  regulations,  as  may  from  time  to  time  be 
established.  The  said  charges  not  to  exceed  the 
actual  cost  of  refining,  casting  and  forming  said 
bars,  including  labor,  wastage,  use  of  machinery, 
material,  etc.  or  \  per  cent,  for  coinage,  to  be  re- 
ceived by  the  Treasurer  of  the  Mint  at  which  the 
deposit  was  made,  and  by  him  accounted  for  to 
the  Treasurer  of  the  United  States. 

Office  hours  from  9  o'clock  A.  M.  to  3  P.  M. 
Bullion  received,  daily,  from  9  o'clock,  A.  M.  to 
12  M.,  and  on  Tuesdays,  from  8  o'clock  A.  M.  to 
12  M.  Visitors  admitted,  daily,  from  9  o'clock 
A.  M.  to  12  o'clock  M. 

CHARLES  H.  HEMPSTEAD,  Sup't. 

Jacob  R.  Snyder,  Treasurer. 

Lafayette  Hammond,  Cashier ;  J.  H.  Snyder. 
Assayer ;  O.  D.  Monson,  Assistant  do. ;  L.  A. 
Garnett,  Melter  and  Refiner;  A.  S.  Garnett,  As- 
sistant do. ;  R.  W.  Slocomb,  Coiner;  R.  B.  San- 
chez, Jesse  Walton,  Reed  Bigler,  E.  B.  Vreeland, 
D.  B.  Hempstead  and  R.  J.  Stevens,  Clerks.

Post-Office. 

N.W.  corner  Washington  and  Battery;  office 
hours  from  8  o'clock  A.  M.  to  5  P.  M.  except  on 
the  arrival  vi'  the  great  Atlantic  Mail,  when  the 
office  is  opened  immediately  after  the  mail  is  dis- 
tributed. 

CHARLES  L.  WELLER,  Post-Master. 

Ferdinand  Crcightou,  Asst.  P.  M. 

J.  A.  Hinehnian.  Post- Master's  Secretary; 
Samuel  M.  Keil'er,  Mailing  Clerk  ;  W.  W.  Arm- 
strong, Box  Clerk;  F.  Martindell.  Registry 
Clerk;  D.  D.  McClelland,  Wm.  Wadhams,  John 
Short,  T.  0.  MeCallan,  L.  II.  Robie  Jr..  Delivery 
Clerks;  F.  B.  Cassas,  Jr.,  Dead  Letter  Clerk;  J. 
W.  Brocas,  Ladies'  Department;  J.  P.  Chamber- 
lain, Newspaper  Clerk;  II.  W.  Butler,  Assistant 
Mailing  Clerk ;  E.  R.  Robinson,  P.  Franklin, 
Porters;   Timothy  Mahony,  Messenger. 

Besides  the  above,  temporary  clerks  are  em- 
ployed on  the  arrival  and  dispatch  of  the  great 
Atlantic  Mail. 

Atlantic  Mails. — The  great  mails  for  the  At- 
lantic States  and  Europe,  leave  on  the  10th,  20th 


and  30th  of  each  month,  except  either  of  these 
dates  tall  on  Sunday,  when  the  mail  leaves  on 
the  succeeding  day.  The  mail  closes  at  the  office 
fifteen  minutes  previous  to  the  sailing  of  the 
Bteamer. 

Great  Overland  Mail,  from  San  Francisco  to 
St.  Louis  and  Memphis.  Tenn.,  via  Los  Angeles, 
Fort  Yuma,  Fort  Fillmore  near  El  Palso,  Preston 
and  Fort  Smith,  leaves  semi-weekly,  Monday 
and  Friday,  at  12  o'clock,  noon;  mail  closes  at 
llf  o'clock,  A.  M. 

Mails  for  Sacramento  and  the  Northern  Mines 
close  daily  at  3:50  P.  M.;  for  Benicia,  Vallejo, 
etc.,  at  the  same  hour. 

Mails  for  Stockton  and  the  Southern  Mines 
close   daily  at  3:50  P.  M. 

Mails  for  San  Jose,  etc.,  close  daily  at  7:50 
A.  M. 

Mails  for  Santa  Barbara,  Los  Angeles  and  San 
Diego,  are  dispatched  regularly  on  the  3d  and 
18th  of  each  month. 

Mails  for  Acapuleo,  Panama,  South  America, 
and  the  West  Indies,  per  great  Atlantic  Mail  on 
the  5th  and  20th  of  each  month. 

Mails  for  China,  the  Sandwich  Islands,  and 
Australia,  are  forwarded  by  the  Post-Otlice  by 
every  suitable  opportunity,  containing  all  letters 
and  papers,  the  inland  postage  of  which  is  pre- 
paid to  San  Francisco — leaving  the  sea  postage 
to  be  collected  in  the  ports  where  the  mails  are 
delivered. 


O  O  TT  IR  T  S  . 


d  States  District  Covrt. — Northern  Dis- 
trict.— Regular  terms  held  in  San  Francisco  first 
Monday  of  June  and  December.  Special  terms 
at  the  discretion  of  the  Court.  Judge,  Hon.  Og- 
den  Hoffman  ;  Attorney,  Calhoun  Benham  :  Mar- 
shal, P.  L.  Solomon  ;  Deputy.  J.  B.  Bell ;  Bailiff, 
L.  D.  Solomon;  Clerk,  W.  H.  Chevers. 

United  States  Circuit  Court — District  of  Cali- 
— Regular  term  held  in  San  Francisco  first 
Monday  of  Jan.  and  July.  Special  terms  at  the 
discretion  of  the  Court.  Judge,  Hon.  M.  Hall

CHURCHES. 


BAPTIST. 

First  Baptist  Church. 

Rev.  D.  B.  Cheney.  Pastor;  Location,  N  side 
Washington  near  Stockton.  Pastor's  residence, 
SV7  eor  Clay  and  Prospect  Place. 

This  church  was  organized  in  June,  1849,  un- 
der the  labors  of  its  first  pastor,  Rev.  0.  C. 
Wheeler.  The  church  lot  v*is  purchased  in  the 
spring  of  the  year,  for  the  sum  of  $10,000.  The 
first  house  of  worship  was  dedicated  in  August, 
1849,  and  was  the  first  Protestant  house  of  wor- 
ship erected  in  California.  Rev.  0.  C  Wheeler's 
pastorate  ended  in  November,  1851,  who  was 
ded  by  Rev.  B.  Brierly  in  May,  1852.  In 
the  summer  and  fall  of  1853,  the  wooden  building 
was  removed,  and  the  basement  of  the  present 
edifice  erected  at  a  cost  of  $13,000.  In  this  the 
church  worshipped  until  September,  1857.  when 
it  dedicated  its  newly  finished  building  which  it 
had  completed  for  the  sum  of  $16,000,  including 
upholstery.  A  new  and  brilliant  toned  organ, 
manufactured  at  the  East,  has  recently  been  ad- 
ded to  the  church. 

Number  of  communicants,  202.  There  is  a 
Sabbath  School  and  two  Bible  classes,  connected 
with  the  church,  and  a  Library,  to  which  valu- 
able additions  have  been  made  during  the  past 
year. 

Sabbath  services  morning  and  evening :  Sab- 
bath School  at  1  P.  M.  Prayer  Meeting  every 
Wednesday  evening;  Sabbath  School  Teachers' 
Meeting  held  on  three  Friday  evenings  of  each 
month,  conducted  by  the  Pastor;  Church  Cove- 
nant Meeting  the  Friday  evening  preceding  the 
first  Sabbath  in  each  month. 

Officers. — Deacons,  Abrm.  Hobson,  A.  B. 
Forbes.  D.  X.  Breed  and  J .  F.  Pope ;  Trustees, 
John  Reynolds,  G.  W.  Dam,  G.  S.  Geddes,  A.  B. 
Forbes  and  P.  Sather;  Clerk,  Alfred  P.  Phipps; 
Treasurer,  D.  C.  Breed ;  Superintendent  of  Sab- 
bath School,  A.  B.  Forbes ;  number  of  members, 
300. 


Olive  Branch  Baptist  Church. 

Rev.  D.  H.  Johnson,  Pastor;  Location.  Mission 
between  Second  and  Third.  Residence  of  Pastor, 
S  side  Mission  between  Second  and  Third. 

Preaching  every  Sabbath  at  11  o'clock  A.  It, 
and  at  7-J  P.  M.  Sabbath  School  commences  at 
24  o'clock  P.  M. ;  Prayer  Meeting  every  Sabbath 
evening,  commencing  at  6£  o'clock ;  Prayer 
and  Conference  Meeting  every  Thursday  even- 
ing at  Ik  o'clock;  Bible  Class  and  Teachers' 
Meeting  every  Friday  evening  at  7 2  o'clock. 

Third  Baptist  Church  (Colored.) 
Organized  in  1854,  is  at  the  present  time  with- 
out a  minister,  and  consists  of  33  members. 
Charles  R.  Kline,  Church  Clerk. 


CONGREGATION  ALIST. 
First   Congregationalist    Church. 

Rev.  Edward  S.  Lacy,  Pastor ;  Location,  SW 
corner  of  California  and  Dupout.  Pastor's  resi- 
dence. S  side  California  near  Powell. 

Has  preaching  every  Sabbath  at  11  o'clock  A. 
M.,  and  7-J  P.  M. ;  Lecture  every  "Wednesday 
evening  at  7  J  o'clock ;  Sabbath  School  imme- 
diately after  morning  service. 

Officers  of  Church. — Deacons,  L.  B.  Benchley, 
Edward  P.  Flint,  Lyman  Dickerman  and  L.  P. 
Fisher:  Standing  Committee,  W.  O.  Ayres,  J. 
W.  Clark,  Ira  P.  Rankin  and  J.  Archbald. 

Officers  of  the  Society. — Ira  P.  Rankin,  Mod- 
erator; George  H.  Kellogg,  Clerk;  Edward  P. 
Flint,  Treasurer ;  Trustees,  J.  W.  Clark,  Ira  P. 
Rankin,  Samuel  Adams,  Wm.  A.  Dana,  Edward 
P.  Flint  and  O.  B.  Jennings. 

This  church,  or  congregation,  was  organized 
July  29,  1849,  when  Thomas  Douglass  and  Fred- 
erick S.  Hawley  were  chosen  Deacons,  and  in- 
ducted into  office  on  the  following  Sunday  by 


APPENDIX. 


433 


Rev.  T.  D.  Hunt,  assisted  by  Rev.  A.  Williams. 
The  society  met  in  the  school-house  on  the  Plaza 
until  it  was  required  for  other  purposes,  when 
the  members  were  deprived  of  a  regular  place  of 
meeting  fur  several  mouths.  As  early  as  prac- 
ticable, however,  efforts  were  made  for  the  erec- 
tion of  a  suitable  house  of  worship,  which  resulted 
in  the  building  of  a  commodious  frame  structure, 
26  by  50  feet,  on  the  corner  of  Jackson  and  Vir- 
ginia streets,  which  was  dedicated  to  the  worship 
of  God,  February  10.  1850.  Rev.  T.  D.  Hunt  was 
chosen  pastor,  and  installed  June  26,  1850,  who 
in  this  connection,  it  is  proper  to  state,  was  the 
first  Protestant  clergyman,  located  as  such,  in 
the  State,  having  arrived  at  San  Francisco  as 
early  as  October  29,  1848,  and  was  immediately 
invited  by  the  citizens,  in  a  meeting  called  for 
the  purpose,  to  act  as  their  chaplain  for  one  year, 
commencing  November  1,  1848,  in  which  capacity 
he  was  laboring  at  the  time  of  the  organization 
of  this  church.  The  congregation  increased  so 
greatly  as  to  require  a  larger  house;  accord- 
ingly, measures  were  adopted  in  the  summer  of 
1852,  for  the  erection  of  the  present  substantial 
brick  edifice,  which  was  dedicated  on  the  10th  of 
July,  1853.  Rev.  E.  S.  Lacy  was  installed  July 
6th,  1856. 

The  whole  number  of  members  admitted  to  the 
church  since  its  organization  has  been  399.  The 
present  membership  is  308.  Number  at  present 
connected  with  the  Sabbath  School,  of  scholars 
and  teachers.  Is  about  500 ;  average  attendance, 
300.  The  cost  of  the  present  church  property, 
including  lot.  building  and  repairs,  has  been 
about  $70,000. 

lay  School. — Superintendent,  L.  B.  Bench- 
ley;  Assistant,  F.P.Flint;  number  of  scholars, 
240;  Teachers,  50.  A  valuable  and  instructive 
Library  of  over  2.000  volumes  is  attached  to  the 
Sabbath  School. 

Congregational  Church. 

Rev.  J.  E.  Benton*,  Pastor;  Location,  Mission 
Dolor 

Public  service  every  Sunday  at  11  o'clock  A. 
M.  Sunday  School  immediately  after  service; 
number   of  scholars.  45. 

There  is  a  society  but  no  church  in  connection 
with  the  congregation. 


EPISCOPAL. 

Grace  Church. 

Rkv.  F.  C.  Ewer,  Rector:  Rev.  Mr.  Jackson, 
officiating;  Location,  W  side  Powell  between 
Jackson  and  Pacific. 

Public  services  every  Sunday  at  11  A.  M.,  and 
11  P.  ML;  Sunday  School  at  half-past  1  in  the 
afternoon.  This  convenient  structure  was  erected 
in  1851,  and  is  one  of  the  oldest  in  the  city.  The 
congregation  was  organized  in  1849,  the  statis- 
tics of  which  may  be  summed  up  as  follows: 
Communicants.  200  ;  the  Sunday  School  num- 
bers about  1,000  scholars,  and  has  a  library  of 
over  three  hundred  volumes.     The  first  rector  of 


the  church  was  Dr.  J.  L.  Ver  Mehr,  who  preached 
his  first  sermon  in  California  at  the  house  of  Mr. 
Merrill,  in  this  city,  September  loth.  1849.  The 
Church  was  then  in  embryo,  not  yet  having  been 
duly  organized.  A  party  of  gentlemen  soon  after 
invited  Dr.  Ver  Mehr  to  preach  at  Frank  Ward's 
house,  situated  on  the  corner  of  Stockton  and 
Green  streets.  A  chapel  was  next  built  towards 
the  close  of  1849,  at  the  corner  of  John  and 
Powell  streets,  which  was  lirst  opened  for  divine 
services,  December  30th,  1849.  This  was  the 
first  Grace  Church.  It  was  60  feet  long  by  20 
feet  wide,  and  cost  $8,000.  The  bell  is  that 
used  in  the  present  Grace  Church,  on  Powell 
Street,  It  weighed  800  pounds,  cost  $350,  and 
has  called  the  faithful  to  prayers  from  the  first. 
It  was  presented  by  Mr.  Frank  Ward.  On  the 
28th  of  April,  1850,  Grace  Church  was  formally 
organized,  and  came  into  being.     E.  Bryant  and 

D.  S.  Turner  were  elected  "Wardens,  and  Dr.  Ver 
Mehr  chosen  Rector.  The  first  vestry  meeting 
was  held  on  the  20th  May,  1850 — ten  years  ago. 
In  February,  1851,  the  contract  was  made  to  build 
the  present  Grace  Church  on  Powell  Street, 
which  was  finished  that  summer.  Its  dimen- 
sions are  68  h  feet  in  length,  and  38  feet  4  inches 
in  width.  The  entire  length,  counting  the  chan- 
cel, is  97  feet  4  inches.  The  tower  is  60  feet  in 
hight.  Dr.  Ver  Mehr  preached  the  first  sermon 
in  this  edifice.  Bishop  Kip  arrived  in  San  Fran- 
cisco January  29th,  1854,  aud  on  the  25th  of 
February  following,  assumed  the  Rectorship,  at 
Which  time  Dr.  Ver  Mehr  resigned.  The  Bishop 
continued  to  officiate  until  Palm  Sunday.  April 
5th,  1857,  when  F.  C.  Ewer  was  ordained',  and  on 
the  next  Sunday  he  preached  his  first  sermon. 
On  the  14th  of  April  Mr.  Ewer  was  elected  to  be 
Assistant  Minister,  and  on  the  20th  of  the  same 
month  he  took  charge  of  the  Parish — the  Bishop 
having  departed  for  the  Atlantic  States.  The 
Bishop  having  returned  and  resigned  the  Rect- 
orship, Mr.  Ewer  was  elected  Rector  of  the 
Church  on  the  15th  of  December,  1857,  and  has 
retained  that  position  to  the  present  time. 

The  congregation  are  now  erecting  at  the  SE 
corner  Stockton  and  California  streets,  a  commo- 
dious and  substantial  church  edifice,  which  will 
be.  when  completed,  one  of  the  finest  church 
buildings  on  the  coast.  The  church  will  cover 
an  area  of  137i  feet  by  68  feet,  and  will  contain 
within  its  walls  every  convenience  necessary  to 
carry  out  the  holy  objects  for  which  it  was 
erected. 

Officers.— Wardens,  J.  W.  Wilde,  Sr.,  Wm. 
Blanding,   Jr. ;  Vestrymen,   R,  J.   Vandewater, 

E.  Pringle,  Stephen  Smith,  D.  S.  Turner,  G.  W. 
Gibbs,  II.  F.  Williams,  and  H.  C.  Parker. 

Trinity  Church. 

Rev.  S.  C.  Thrall,  Rector;  Location,  N  side 
Pine  between  Montgomery  and  Kearny ;  Rector's 
residence,  Lombard  between  Kearny  and  Du- 
pont;  Organized,  1850. 

Services,  Sunday,  11  o'clock  A.  M.,  and  7  J  P. 
M.;  daily  11  A.  M.,  Friday  4  P.  M. ;  Sunday 
School,  9i  A.  M. 

Officers.— Wardens,  J.  D.  Hawks,  Sr.,  W.  F. 
Babcock,  Jr. ;  Vestrymen,  II.   P.   Janes,    S.  R.

Throckmorton,  Louie  McLane,  J.  Underbill,  Jas. 
Bell,  and  James  Alden;  Secretary,  J.  fj.  East- 
land; Treasurer,  B.  II.  Randolph;'  Organist,  II. 
Rasche. 

St.  John's  Church,  Mission  Dolores. 

Rev.  J.    Oambrok,    Pastor;    Residence  near 
Mission  Dolores. 

This  Church  was  established  in  X. member, 
1857— the  Rev.  John  Chittenden,  President  ofthe 
San  Francisco  College,  then  alayreader, : 
by  the  Bishop  oi  the  Diocese,  officiating  as  its 
minister.  The  parish,  of  which  this  is  the 
church,  was  instituted  in  February,  1868,  audit 
is  now  in  a  state  of  forwardness,  to  be  perma- 
nently received  as  Buoh  into  the  Diocese  of  Cali- 
fornia. It  is  ofthe  Protestant  EpiSCOpall 
and  has  all  the  privileges  of  other  churc 

nscopate.     it   is  a  neat    edifice,    and   is 
ighly  furnished  with  organ,  robing-i 
altar,  pulpit  anil  vestment.      The  inhabits! 

Indebted  mainly  to  the  liberality  of  a  few  indi- 
viduals and  to  the  Rev.  John  Chittenden  for  the 
first  introduction  of  this  church  service  into  the 
neighborhood.  The  Rev.  J.  Cameron,  ordained 
in  A]. ril  last,  now  officiates  as  Curat.'— the  Rev. 
J.  Chittenden  being  his  Rector.  By  the  energy 
of  the  present  Curate,  assisted  by  his  brother 
clergymen,  he  has  established  the  Episcopal 
Church  permanently  in  this  vicinity.  Services 
are  held  at  different  hours,  from  11  A.  M.  to  3 
P.  M.,  to  suit  the  attendants.  It  is  worthy  of 
being  noted,  that  the  Ministers,  Organist  (Mr. 
Theodore  Smith).  Choir,  and  other  assistants. 
give  their  services  gratuitously.  The  church  can 
accommodate  upwards  of  200"persons. 

Church  of  the  Advent. 

Rev.  F.  Marion  McAllister,  Rector :  Resi- 
dence, 278  Clay. 

The  Church  was  established,  with  its  first  and 
present  Rector,  June,  1858. 

This  church  is  located  at  present  on  the  South 
side  of  Mission  Street  near  Second  Street.  A  lot 
has  been  purchased  by  the  congregation  on 
Howard  between  Second  and  Third  streets, 
which  is  now  being  graded  for  a  building— the 
erection  of  which  will  be  commenced  about  the 
first  of  August. 

Services  every  Sunday  at  11  A.  M..  and  7|P. 
M. ;  Sunday  School  at  9£  A.  M. 

The  Sunday  School  of  this  Church  was  or- 
ganized February,  1858.

METHODIST  EPISCOPAL. 

Powell  Street  Church. 
Rev.  Jesse  T.  Peck,  P.  P..  Pastor;  Resi- 
dence, N  side  Washington  above  Powell;  Loca- 
tion, W  side  Powell  between  Washington  and 
Jackson;  organized  in  the  autumn  of  1849,  by 
Rev.  William  Taylor.  During  that  season  a 
small  building  received  from  Oregon  was  erected 
on  the  half  of  a  fifty -vara  lot,  which  had  been  ob- 
tained from  Mr.  John  Trubody.  In  the  year  1851 
this  building  was  enlarged;  in  1852,  it  was  re- 
moved to  give  place  to  the  present  structure, 
which  was  opened  for  public  worship  in  Febru- 
ary, 1853.  Number  of  communicants,  195. 
Preaching  on  Sunday  at  11  A.  M..  and  7i  P.  M. 
Sunday  School  2£  P.  M.  Sabbath  School  Super- 
intendent, John  Burns,  Jr.  Number  of  teachers, 
37  ;  scholars,  225. 

Methodist  Episcopal  Church,  South- 
Rev.  0.  P.  Fitzgerald,    Pastor;  Residence, 
S  side  Pine  above  Stockton;  Location,  N  side  of 
Pine  Street  between  Montgomery  and  Kearny. 
Re-organized  December,  1858. 

Public  services  Sabbath  morning  and  evening, 
at  11  A.  M.  and  8  o'clock  P.  M.  Praver  meet- 
ing on  Wednesday  evening  at  7£  o'clock.  Sun- 
day School  at  9£  o'clock  on  Sabbath. 

Officers. — Class  Leaders,  C.  L.  Newmans  and 
J.  K.  Washburn ;  Stewards,  D.  0.  Shattuck,  Jos. 
Genella,  W.  B.  Parsons,  Robert  W.  Larrhnore, 
Rufus  K.  Cain,  and  Charles  Spencer. 

Folsom  Street  Methodist  Episcopal  Church,  be- 
tween First  and  Second- 

Rev.  S.  D.  Simoxps,  Pastor;  Residence, rear 
of  church.  Sunday  morning  and  evening  service 
at  the  usual  hours:  seats  free.  Sunday  School 
at  2  o'clock  P.  M.  Prayer  Meeting,  etc.,  on 
Wednesday  evening. 

This  Society,  organized  in  1852,  under  the 
superintendence  of  Rev.  Isaac  Owen,  erected, 
and  dedicated  December  5th,  1853,  a  plain,  but 
substantial,  neatly  furnished  house  of  worship. 
The  Society  has  a  valuable  property  and  is  out 
of  debt.  The  number  of  communicants  was,  in 
September,  1858,  70;  since  which  50  have  been 
added;  making  in  all,  120,  up  to  February  of 
present  year.  A  deep  religious  interest  pervades 
the  society.  Sabbath  School  Superintendent, 
Samuel  S.  Sprague;  number  of  teachers,  24; 
scholars,  160 ;  new  volumes  in  the  Library,  680!

435 


Bethel  Methodist  Episcopal  Church. 

Rev.  0.  IT.  Nortiiup,  Pastor.  Residence,  rear 
of  Church  ;  Location,  Mission  between  First  and 
Second  streets. 

This  Church  was  organized  early  in  1851, 
under  tho  pastoral  charge  of  Rev.  W.  Taylor. 
Service  was  then  held  in  the  ship  Panama,  on 
Davis  street.  Subsequently  the  ship  was  moved 
to  the  foot  of  Mission  Street,  and  a  church  built 
on  deck.  Early  in  1857  the  church  was  taken 
down  and  rebuilt  in  its  present  eligible  situation. 
Services  at  the  usual  hours  on  Sabbath  morning 
and  evening.    Sabbath  School  at  2  P.  M. 

Officers. — J.  M.  Buffington,  John  Kennerson, 
Silas  Parker,  Israel  Richards,  Abraham  Stoner, 
George  A.  Williams,  Thomas  II.  Bryant,  Benja- 
min Currier  and  Thomas  Welsh,  Trustees.  Su- 
perintendent of  Sunday  School,  J.  M.  Buffington; 
Number  of  volumes  in  Library,  300 ;  Sunday 
School  Officers  and  Teachers,  12  ;  Scholars,  70. 

German  Methodist  Church. 

Rev.  Charles  Augustus  E.  Hertel,  Pastor. 
Residence,  Pine  Street,  2d  door  W  of  Dupont,  in 
rear  of  Church;  Location,  NW  corner  of  Pine 
and  Dupont. 

This  congregation  was  organized  by  the  late 
pastor,  the  Rev.  A.  Kellner,  Sept.  21st,  1856, 
who  was  commissioned  to  California  as  a  Mis- 
i  ionary  from  the  M.  E.  Church,  and  arrived  May 
1st,  1856.  The  building  is  of  brick,  36  by  58. 
one  story,  and  was  dedicated  Sept.  21st,  1856. 
Public  services  every  Sunday  at  10  J  A.  M.  and 
7  j  P.  M.  Sunday  School  at  9  A.  M. ;  Superin- 
tendent, Albert  Miller;  number  of  scholars,  110; 
volumes  in  Library,  320.  Prayer  and  Lecture 
every  Wednesday  at  7  A  P.  M. 

German  M.  E.  Church. 

Rev.  Augustus  Kellner,  Pastor.  Organized 
February  20th,  1859.  Residence  in  rear  of  the 
Church  ;  Location,  N  s  Broadway  between  Stock- 
ton and  Powell.  Services  every  Sunday  at  10£ 
A.  M.  and  7*  P.  M.  Sunday  School  at  9  A.  M. 
Services  also  every  Wednesday  evening  at  7£ 
o'clock. 

German  M.  E.  Church. 

Rev.  Augustus  Kellner,  Pastor.  Organized 
4th  April,  1858;  Location,  Mission  Street  be- 
tween Third  and  Fourth.  Services  every  Sunday 
at  3  o'clock  P.  M.     Sunday  School  at  2  P.  M. 

African  Methodist  Episcopal  Church. 

Rev.  J.  B.  Sanderson,  Pastor.  Residence  E 
s  Mason  near  Taylor;  Location,  Scott  street. 

The  society  worshiping  here  is  die  same  that 
formerly  occupied  the  St.  Cyprian  Church.  Un- 
der the  pastorship  of  Rev.  T.  M.  D.  Ward,  they 
re-organized  in  1856,  and  purchased  the  Scott 
Street  Church  property.  Since  April,  1857,  J.  B. 
Sanderson  has  been  the  Pastor  of  this  Church. 
Public  services  every  Sabbath  at  the  usual  hours. 

Methodist  Episcopal  Church,  Zion,  (col'd.) 

Rev.  A.  B.  Smith,  Pastor.  Residence  S  s 
Vallejo  near  Mason;  Location.  Pacific  nr Powell. 

This  congregation  was  organized  by  Rev.  John 


J.  Moore,  the  late  pastor,  August  1st.  1852.    Up 

to  August  L3,  1856,  worship  was  held  in  a  frame 
building  on  Stockton  Street,  opposite  the  Marine 
Hospital,  since    which    service    has  been  held  in 

the  present  brick  edifice,  one  story  of  which  is 
finished.  It  was  dedicated  Sept,  7th,  1856.  The 
expenditure  on  this  building,  thus  far.  has  been 
$4,000.  Attached  to  the  congregation  is  an  in- 
teresting Sabbath  School,  numbering  about  50 
pupils,  G  teachers,  and  a  Library  of  500  vol- 
umes; R.  T.  Houston,  Sup.  Public  Services  and 
Sabbath  School  every  Sunday  at  the  usual  hours. 


PRESBYTERIAN. 
First  Presbyterian  Church. 

Rev.  W.  C.  ANDBBSOK,  D.  D.  Pastor.  Resi- 
dence, E  s  Powell  between  Clay  and  Washing- 
ton ;  Location,  Stockton  Street  nr  Clay.  Services 
on  Sabbath  at  11  o'clock  A.  M.,  and  7^  P.  M.  Sab- 
bath School  and  Bible  Class  at  1  o'clock  P.  M. 
Lecture  on  Wednesday  evening,  at  7-£  o'clock. 

This  Church  was  organized  May  20th,  1849, 
under  the  direction  of  the  Rev.  Albert  Williams, 
and  was  the  first  Protestant  Church  organized  in 
San  Francisco.  W.  W.  Caldwell,  Frederick  Bil- 
lings,  Dr.  Geo.  F.  Turner,  Mrs.  Sarah  B.  Gil- 
lespie, Mrs.  Ann  Hodgson,  and  Mrs.  Margaret  A. 
Geary,  were  the  original  members:  (.'apt,  B.  Sim- 
mons. E.  Woodruff  and  H.  Grimes,  were  the 
first  trustees. 

During  the  summer  of  1849,  the  congregation 
worshiped  in  a  tent  on  Dupont  Street,  after- 
wards in  a  storeroom  of  the  Custom  House,  and 
in  the  Superior  Court  room,  City  Hall,  until 
January  19th,  1851,  when  a  neat  Gothic  edifice, 
capable  of  holding  seven  hundred  persons,  was 
dedicated.  This  house  was  destroyed  by  the 
great  fire  of  22d  June,  1851.  A  plain  building 
was  immediately  erected,  in  which  the  congre- 
gation worshiped  until  August,  1857;  and 
from  that  time  till  May,  1858,  their  meetings 
were  held  in  the  Chinese  Mission  Chapel.  Their 
present  fine  house  of  worship  was  built  in  the 
summer  and  autumn  of  1857.  It  is  in  the 
Gothic  style  of  architecture  throughout.  The 
main  building  is  117  feet  long,  or  to  the  outside 
of  the  tower,  123;  and  is  61  feet  wide.  Rooms 
for  the  Pastor's  study  and  social  meetings,  are 
on  the  same  floor  with  the  audience  room,  which 
last,  is  81  by  58  feet;  with  a  ceiling  :!'.»  feet  high. 
A  Sabbath  School  room  57  by  36,  is  over  the 
front  apartments;  on  the  north-east  corner  of  the 
house,  there  is  a  brick  tower  96  feet  in  hight. 
There  is  an  organ  gallery  which  will  scat  a  choir 
of  forty  persons.  In  all  its  arrangements  the 
edifice  is  admirably  adapted  to  its  purpose,  and 
at  the  same  time,  is  in  accordance  with  true 
architectural  taste. 

Officers — Rev.  W.  C.  Anderson,  D.  D.,  Pas- 
tor;' K.  II.  Waller,  N.  Grav,  S.  Hopkins  and  W. 
W.  Caldwell,  Elders;  John  D.  Arthur,  L.  B.  Ed- 
wards. Samuel  Irving,  Henry  L.  King,  Chileon 
Beach,  James  K.  S.  Latham,  William  Elder, 
. lames  Bowman  and  Richard  J.  Nichols,  Trus- 
tees. 

The  Church  is  in  a  very  prosperous  condition,

SAN     FRANCISCO     DIRECTORY. 


more  than  80  members  having  been  added  to  its 
communion,  and  the  nnmber  of  its  pewholdera 
more  than  doubled  in  Che  nasi  fear.  Present 
number  of  communicants,  220;  Sabbath 
Superintendent,  Nathaniel  dray:  number  of 
teachers,  BO;  average  attendance  of  scholars, 
195  :  a  fine  Library  of  over  2,000  volumes  is  at- 
tached to  the  school. 

Calvary  Presbyterian  Church. 

REV.  W.  A.   Scott,    P.   D.,    Pastor;  Location 

north  side  of  Bush  Street,  hetween  Mm;' 

and  Sansome,     Services  every  Sabbath,  at  11   \. 

M.  anil  at  7  I'.  M..    in  winter  months,    anil  at  74- 

P.  M.  in  summer.  Public  lecture  Wednesday 
evening;  Prayer  Meeting  Sabbath  evening,  one 
hour  before  the  evening  service:  Sabbath  School 
every  Sabbath  at  1  P.  M.,  H.  P.  Coon,  Superin- 
tendent. 

-—Klders,  R.  McKce.  Stephen  Franklin, 
Henry  I'.  Coon,  .lames  P.  Thornton,  James  B. 
Roberts :  Deacons,  Edward  Hagthrop,  Z.  Snyder; 
Trustees.  F.  Henderson.  John  Middleton,  James 
B.  Roberts,  H.  II.  Haightj  A.  P.  Sanford.  R.  B. 
Woodward,  A.  Campbell  IT.  H.  Bancroft  and  H. 
M.  NewhaJl. 

This  church  was  erected  in  the  fall  of  1854,  at 
a  cost,  including  the  lot,  of  about  $70,000.  On 
its  completion,  the  property  was  largely  in  debt, 
but  the  debt  was  gradually  reduced,  and  finally 
wholly  extinguished  in  the  fall  of  the  last  year. 
The  whole  property  is  now  entirely  free  from 
debt,  and  the  income  of  the  church,  now  some 
$13,000,  from  pew  rents  and  Sabbath  collections, 
is  ample  to  meet  all  its  current  expenses.  Dur- 
ing the  past  summer,  a  splendid  organ,  built  by 
Henry  Erben,  of  New  York,  was  put  up  in  the 
church,  at  a  cost  of  over  $8,000.  Tins  is,  in  all 
respects,  the  largest  and  most  costly  organ  on 
the  Pacific  coast,  and  it  has  few  superiors  even  in 
the  Atlantic  States.  It  has  46  stops,  and  over 
2,000  pipes.  The  greatest  variety  of  combina- 
tions can  be  made  by  the  use  of  the  various  stops 
and  couplings ;  and  for  excellence  of  workman- 
ship, and  sweetness  of  tone,  it  has  been  pro- 
nounced by  judges  to  be  unsurpassed. 

Mr.  fr.  T.  Evans,  presides  as  organist.  The 
church  building  will  seat  comfortably  1,000  per- 
sons. The  number  of  communicants  is  now 
about  300 ;  the  number  of  scholars  and  teachers 
in  the  Sabbath  School  is  about  175  ;  number  of 
volumes  in  the  Library,  1,000,  which  were  se- 
lected with  great  care,  and  form  a  very  complete 
Library.  Connected  with  the  church  is  a  deposi- 
tory of  the  books  of  the  Presbyterian  Board  of 
Publication,  in  which  there  is  kept  a  variety  of 
the  standard  books  and  tracts  published  by  that 
board. 

Howard  Presbyterian  Church. 

Rev.  S.  II.  Willet,  Pastor ;  Location,  corner 
Natoma  and  Jane,  near  Howard  Street. 

Organized  September,  1850,  to  supply  a  por- 
tion of  the  city  (Happy  Valley),  then  destitute  of 
religious  privileges.  Under  "the  auspices  of  the 
present  pastor,  the  building  at  present  occupied 
by  the  congregation  was  dedicated  June  17, 
1851.     It  has  recently  been  enlarged  and  thor- 


oughly repaired,  and  now  contains  a  neat  and 
COmmodiOUS  audience  room — beside  Lecture

Welsh  Presbyterian  Church. 

Location,  Pollard  Place,  north  side  Vallejo 
between  Dupont  and  Kearny. 

This  church  is  at  present  closed. 

Chinese  Mission  Chapel. 
Rev.  A.  W.  LOOMS,  Pastor;  Residence,  NE 
corner  Sacramento  and  Stockton;  Location.  NE 
corner  Stockton  and  Sacramento  streets.  Relig- 
ious services  in  the  Chinese  language  on  Sabbath 
at  11  o'clock,  and  also  on  Thursday  evenings. 
A  day  school  is  also  kept  throughout  the  week. 
The  house  is  brick,  and  was  built  by  the  liber- 
ality of  the  citizens  of  San  Francisco.  It  con- 
tains school  rooms  in  the  basement;  on  the  first 
floor  a  chapel  which  will  seat  two  hundred  per( 
sons,  and  on  the  second,  apartments  for  the  ac- 
commodation of  the  missionionary  family. 

The  Mariners'   Church. 

Rev.  J.  Rowell.  Pastor ;  Residence,  Bernard 
near  Taylor;  Location,  Clark  Street. 

This  Church  was  organized  with  six  members, 
in  December,  1858,  and  now  consists  of  thirty. 
Public  worship  every  Sabbath  at  3  o'clock  P.  M. 
There  is  connected  with  the  Church  a  Sabbath 
School,  consisting  of  about  40  scholars,  with  1 2 
teachers.  The  house  of  worship,  is  a  commodi- 
ous wooden  building,  on  Clark  Street,  near 
Drunim.  It  was  erected  some  years  since,  by 
contributions  from  merchants,  and  other  citizens 
of  San  Francisco. 

Officers. — Rev.  J.  Rowell,  Pastor,  and  Chaplain 
of  the  American  Seamen's  Friend  Society,  who 
has  labored  here  since  Augnst,  1858;  Obed 
Chart  and  James  F.  Stewart,  Peacons. 

During  the  present  year,  a  society  has  been 
formed  among  the  business  men  of  San  Francisco, 
having  for  its  object  the  moral  improvement  of 
seamen,  called  The  San  Francisco  Port  Society. 
It  seeks  to  attain  its  object  by  sustaining  the 
preaching  of  the  Gospel,  and  other  missionary 
labors,  in  connection  with  the  Mariners'  Church. 
The  officers  of  the  society  for  the  present  year, 
are  Judge  H.  P.  Coon,  President ;  Ira  P.  Rankin, 
Vice-President;  J.  Rowell,  Secretary;  O.  B. 
Jennings.  Treasurer ;  Capt.  J.  C.  Hoyt,  ('apt.  J. 
B.  Thomas,  O.  B.  Jennings,  Nathaniel  Gray,  P. 
Sather,  E.  "W.  Church,  Louis  McLane,  J.  Rowell, 
and  James  F.  Stewart,  Trustees. 

Church  of  Christ. 

Members  of  the  Church  of  Christ  (Pisciples) 
service  is  held  on  every  Lord's  Day  morning  at  11 
o'clock,  at  the  French  College,  corner  of  Jackson 
and  Mason  streets.

tween Third  ami  Fourth.  Hours  of  worship  as 
usual  iu  other  churches  in  tho  city. 


ROMAN  CATHOLIC. 
St.  Mary's  Cathedral. 

Most  Rev.  Joseph  8.  Alemany,  Archbishop; 
Rev.  James  Croke,  V.  Gh  Pastor;  Revd's  John 
Harrington   and  J.  Cotter,  Assistants.     Archi- 

episcopal  anil  pastoral  residence,  Dupont  Street, 
adjoining-  the  Cathedral  Location,  N.  E.  corner 
California  and  Dupont  streets.  Masses,  Sundays 
at  6£,  9  and  11  o'clock  A.  M. ;  week  days,  6i,  7 
and  7 £  o'clock  A.  M. ;  Vespers  at  7  o'clock,  Sun- 
day evenings. 

The  erection  of  this  noble  structure  was  com- 
menced on  the  17th  of  July,  1853,  during  which 
year  the  basement  portion  was  built,  and  tho 
work  was  resumed  the  .Inly  following.  Dedi- 
cated December  '25,  1854  The  Church  is  seventy- 
;,  wide,  fronting  on  California  Street,  by 
131  feet  on  Dupont  Street,  being  the  largest 
church  iu  the  State.  A  portion  of  the  basement 
is  now  used  for  a  school  and  a  library,  the  rest 
being  reserved  for  a  small  chapel.  Service  was 
begun  at  midnight  on  December  24,  1854.  The 
basement  portion,  which  is  19  feet  high,  is  light- 
ed from  both  sides  and  well  ventilated.  The 
present  expenditure  on  the  building  is  #140,000, 
and  will  require  $15,000  more  to  complete  it. 
The  Church  portion  is  45  feet  high  in  the  clear 
and  contains  spacious  galleries  and  an  organ  loft. 
'1'lie  ceilings  are  vaulted  with  a  series  of  groined 
arches  which  are  decorated,  and  every  means 
has  been  resorted  to  for  accommodation,  light 
and  ventilation.  The  Church  can  seat  twelve 
hundred  persons.  The  tower  is  at  present  135 
feet  high,  ami  when  completed,  witii  the  spire, 
will  be  200  feet  high,  flu-  edifice  is  of  Gothic 
architecture,  which  has  been  carried  out  in  every 
detail  through  the  building.  In  all  the  arrange- 
ments for  the  erection  of  the  Church,  the  greatest 
attention  has  been  paid  to  the  selection  of  the 
best  materials,  and  to  the  combination  of  strength 
and  durability,  which  are  admirably  effected  in 
its  construction.     Craine  &  England,   architects. 

St.  Francis. 

Very  Rev.  Petkr  MAeaOGNOTTO,  V.  General, 
Pastor;  Rev.  Thomas  Cian,  (Chinese)  assistant, 
Pastoral  residence  S  s  Green  near  Dupont ;  Loca- 
tion N  s  Vallejo  bet  Dupont  and  Stockton.  Ser- 
vices, Sunday  Gf,  8-J  and  11  A.M.;  Sunday- 
School,  2  o'clock  P.  M.,  and  evening  devotions 
at  7  o'clock  P.  M.  ;  at  8&  o'clock  P.  M.  the  ser- 
mon is  in  Spanish. 

This  Church  was  organized  by  Very  Rev.  An 


in  San  Francisco.  Its  ground  base  was  40  by 
Itio  feet,  one  story  in  bight.  During  the  pa.-t 
year  a  large  and  commodious  Church  ha 
erected,  which  was  dedicated  on  the  17th  March 
last.  Its  design  is  of  the  Gothic  order,  preva- 
lent in  the  fourteenth  century,  presenting  an  illus- 
tration of  the  Christian  Architecture  of  that  pe- 
riod. The  principal  features  of  this  imposing 
structure  are  the  t  >wers,  which  project  beyond 
the  body  of  the  C  lurch,  and  present  in  their  ele- 
vation four  divi.  Ions,  rising  to  a  bight  of  SO 
feet  from  the  ground.  The  entrance  porch,  fit 
vestibule,  has   two    side  aisles,  a   semi-oclagoiul 

sanctuary,  and  two  sacristies,  and  is  approached 
by  a  flight  of  ten  steps,  ascending  to  ttie  vesti- 
bule, from  which,  at  each  side,  are  entrances  o 
the  galleries  and  baptistry,  and  in  front  are  tie 
pointed  arch  doorways  which  lead  to  the  na  e 
and  aisles.  In  the  central  Space,  between  the 
towers,  are  the  three  doorways  coiuuninieatiiig 
with  the  vestibule,  and  thence  with  the  interior. 
Over  the  central  door  there  is  a  large  and  elega  it 
three-COmpartment  window,  and  in  the  gable,  a 
highly  decorated  rose  window.  Over  each  sM 
door,  there  is  a  lofty  and  spacious  niche,  which 
rises  from  richly  moulded  brick  corbels ;  there 
are,  also,  three  marble  panels,  with  appropriate 
inscriptions,  recessed  in  the  brickwork  imme- 
diately over  each  doorway  and  the  gable ;  the 
work  is  finished  with  a  massive  and  richly  deco- 
rated cross. 

The  cast  and  west  sides  of  the  structure  are 
divided  by  buttresses  into  eight  spaces,  in  each 
instance;  seven  of  which  contain  the  large 
pointed  arch  windows  which  light  the  Church, 
Beneath  the  lloor  of  the  Church,  there  is  a  large 
and  well-lighted  basement,  which  is  to  be  used 
as  a  school-room,  and  also  as  a  place  of  meeting 
for  the  parishioners.  The  extreme  length  of  the 
building  is  06  by  137  £  feet ;  from  the  lloor  to  the 
foot  of  the  rafters,  is  35  feet  The  cost  to  com- 
plete, will  be  nearly  $100,000.

SWEDENBORGIAN. 

New  Jerusalem  Church. 

Public  service  held  every  Sabbath  morning  at 
II  o'clock  A.  M.,  and  .Bible  class  at  2*  o'clock 
P;  M.,  in  the  rooms  of  the  Twelfth  District  Court, 
City  Hall.  Administration  of  the  Sacrament  of 
the  Lord' 8  Supper,  at  the  residence  of  Dr.  M  J. 
Burke,  .N  s  Ulay  above  Stockton,  on  the  first 
Sundays  of  January,  April,  July  and  October,  at 
2  j  o  clock  P.  M. 

Officers — President,  Tlios.  S.  Miller ;  Treasurer,

A  Library,  containing  all  the  Scientific  and 
Theological  works  of  Swedenborg,  and  a  large 
collection  of  the  collateral  works  of  the  iSew 
Church,  both  English  and  American,  is  kept  at 
Dr.  Kellogg' s  Drug  Store,  on  Jackson  Street 
above  Montgomery. 

The  cntiicu  was  organized  in  1851. 


UNITARIAN. 
Fir3t  Unitarian  Church. 

Rev.  Thomas  Stake  King,  Pastor.     Location, 
West  side  of  Stockton  Street,  between  Clay  and 


Sacramento  sis.  Services  every  Sunday  at  1  1  A. 
M.  and  at  7  A  P.  M.      Sabbath  School  at  I   - 

1'.  M. :  Pastor's  residence.  Oriental  HoteL    This 

society  was  organized  in  September,  I860.    The 

present   building  was   erected  in  1862,  and   was 

uedioated  July  17th.  1863,  by  the  Bev.  Fred.  T. 
Gray,  the  second  pastor,  who  arrived  here  in 
June.  1863,  and  lefi  in  June,  1864,  and  died  in 
Boston  in  February,  L866.  The  first  regular 
pastor.  Joseph  Harrington,  arrived  here 
27th,    1862,   and  died    November   2d,  of  same 

year,  from  disease  contracted  during  the  voyage 
from  Panama.  The  third  regular  pastor,  the 
Rev.  U.  P.  Cutler,  arrived  here  August  .''.1st, 
1864,  began  his  ministrations  Sept.  10th,  1854, 
and  which  were  continued  without  intermission 
until  the  lirst  day  of  June,  L859,  at  which  time 
he  resigned  his  charge,  and  left  for  Xew  York 
on  the  5th  J uiic.  1869.     The  present  pastor,  the 

Rev.  Thomas  Starr  King,  late  of  Boston,  undone 

of  the  most  eloquent  and  earnest  divines  of  the 

i  day.  arrived  here,  with  his  family,  on 
the  28th  day  of  April  1860.  Mr.  King  com- 
menced his  ministrations  at  once,  and  preached 
the  following  day  (Sunday)  to  one  of  the  largest 
congregations  ever  assembled  in  this  city.  The 
church  was  densely  crowded,  and  many  persons 
were  unable  to  gain  admittance.  After  the  de- 
parture of  the  Rev.  Mr.  Cutler,  and  until  the  ar- 
rival of  the  present  pastor,  the  Rev.  T.  S.  King,  the 
pulpit  was  temporarily  filled  by  the  Rev.  Jno. 
A.  Buckingham,  during  the  space  of  ten  months, 
and  until  his  departure  for  New  York,  April  5, 
1860.  This  church  has  lately  undergone  exten- 
sive repairs  and  improvements,  both  the  interior 
and  exterior,  and  is  now  one  of  the  most  attract 
ive  places  of  public  worship  in  this  city.  It  is 
capable  of  seating  upwards  of  1,000  persons. 

The  original  officers  of  the  Society  were  :  F. 
W.  Macondray,  Wm.  Hooper,  S.  P.  Dewey,  Jas. 
King  of  Wm.  and  P.  A.  Hussey,  Directors  ;  Geo. 
F.  Noyes,  Clerk,  and  John  Perry,  Jr.,  Treasurer. 

Present  Ojjictra — Moderator,  R.  B.  Swain  ; 
Treasurer,  Wm.  C.  Hinckley;  Clerk,  Wm.  A. 
Macondray; •Trustees,  James  Otis,  F.  A.  Hol- 
inan,  Geo.  H.  Davis,  Wm.  Newell,  D.  C.  McRuer 
and  F.  H.  Woods. 

The  "  Pilgrim  Sunday  School,"  connected  with 
this  church,  is  one  of  the  largest  and  most  flour- 
ishing institutions  of  the  kind  in  the  city.  Super- 
intendent, Saiul.  H.  Lloyd ;  Ass't  Supts.,  John 
Gv  Dawes,  and  Miss  Anna  P.  Webb ;  Treasurer, 
Henry  Kimball  ;  Librarian,  Win.  J.  Younger. 
Number  of  Teachers,  41;  average  attendance  of 
scholars,  upwards  of  260.  There  is  an  extensive, 
valuable,  and  gradually-  increasing  library  con- 
nected with  this  school,  already  numbering  up- 
wards of  2,300  volumes.

SABBATH  SCHOOL  UNION.— Reorganized 
May,  1857.  The  Union  meets  monthly,  alter- 
nating at  the  different  churches  whose  schools 
are  represented  in  the  Union,  when  reports  from 
the  different  schools,  showing  the  average  at- 
tendance of  scholars  and  teachers  for  the  pre- 
vious month,  are  presented. 

Officers — President,  A.  B.  Forbes,  First  Baptist 
Church;  Vice-Presidents,  Dr.  F.  Knox,  Howard 
Street  Presbyterian,  1.  Burns,  Powell  Street 
Methodist,  Henry  J.  Wells,  first  Baptist ;  Secre- 
tary and  Treasurer,  John  McKee,  Calvary  Pres- 
byterian.

ganized March,  1860.

aiding  the  parent  society  in  6  ining  the  Mar- 
iner's Church  of  San  Francisfl  uid  in  such  en- 
terprises connected  therewith  as  the  Society 
may  approve.  Any  person  may  become  a  mem- 
ber by  paying  five  dollars  a  year,  or  a  life-mem- 
ber  by  the  payment  at  one  time  of  fifty  dollars.

YOUNG  MEN'S  CHRISTIAN  ASSOCIA- 
TION.— t  Irganized  July,  1853.  Rooms,  17U 
Washington  Street,  between  Montgomery  and 

Kearny.  This  association  is  designed  especially 
to  promote  the  moral,  intellectual  and  social  im- 
provement of  the  young  men  of  San  Francisco, 

and  is  wholly  free  from  sectarian  aims  and  influ- 
ences. The  reading  rooms  arc  supplied  with  all 
the   leading  and  foreign   papers  and 

magazines.  ry  contains  about  1,400 

volumes,  and  daily  from  3  to  10  P.  M., 

except  Sunda  as  of  membership — The 

payment  of  ai  anual  fee  of  five  dollars  con- 
stitutes an  active  member,  and  of  three  dollars 
sociate  member.  A  payment  of  twenty- 
five  dollars  constitutes  a  life  member  without 
further  dues. 

Officers — President,  E.  D.  Sawyer;  Recording 
Secretary,    George   T.    Hawley;    Corresponding 
ry,   Daniel  C.  Breed;  Treasurer,  J.  K.  6. 
Latham;  Librarian,  H.  L.  Chamberlain. 


Benevolent. 

ORPHAN  ASYLUM,  (CATHOLIC)— Market 
near  Kearny  street  Organized  March  23d, 
L861,  and  placed  under  the  care  of  the  Sisters  of 
Charity.  A  frame  building  for  this  purpose  was 
commenced  in  July,  and  completed  in  September, 
1851 ;  it  was  occupied  in  part  for  a  school,  and 
a  portion  was  temporarily  used  as  a  church, 
under  the  pastoral  charge  of  Rev.  John  Magin- 
nis.  The  present  spacious  brick  building  was 
completed  in  November,  1854,  at  a  cost  of 
$45,000.  It  is  a  source  of  gratification  to  behold 
the  consoling  appearance  presented  by  the  235 
little  ones  now  provided  for  in  the  Institution, 
which  speaks  audibly  of  the  benign  influence  of 
their  guardian  Sisters,  and  of  the  true  liberality 
of  our  community  in  their  noble  efforts  to  lend  a 
helping  hand  to  the  fatherless.  Another  spacious 
brick  building,  of  the  same  dimensions  as  that 
erected  in  1854,  was  completed  within  the  last 
year  for  a  school,  in  which  550  children  receive 
education  gratis.  The  asylum  is  conducted 
under  the  sole  management  of  Archbishop  Ale- 
many,  Rev.  John  Maginnis,  and  the  Sisters  of 
Charity. 


ORPHAN  ASYLUM  (PROTESTANT.)  — 
Organized  January  31,  1851,  and  incorporated 
February  1".  1851.  Original  officers — President, 
Mrs.  Albert  Williams ;  Vice  President,  Mrs.  S. 
II.  Willey;  Secretary,  Mrs.  B,  A.  Warren;  Treas- 
urer, Mrs.  Boring;  Managers,  Mrs.  I!.  II.  Waller, 
Mr-.  0.  V.Gillespie,  Mrs.  Taylor,  Mrs.  VerMehr, 
Mrs.  Joice,  and  Mrs.  o.  C.Wheeler;  Ti 
Charles  Gilmore,  D.  L  Ross,  and  S.  Franklin. 
It  originally  oc<  upied  the  building  on  the  corner 
of  Second  and  Folsom  Btreets,  owned  by  Mr. 

llalleek.  whence  they  removed  the  children  in 
March.  L864,  to  the  present  building,  jut 
completed  ai  a  cost  of  $30,000.  This  house, 
built  of  stone  and  brick,  expressly  for  the  pur- 
-  highly  creditable  to  the  institution,  and 
one  of  the  noblest  monuments  of  San  Francisco 
benevolence.  Present  number  of  children  under 
the  care  of  the  Asylum  is  62. 

Officers — President.  Mrs.  P.  H.  Waller;  Vice

DEAF,  DUMB  AND  BLIND  INSTITUTION. 
— School,  15  Tehama  ;  organized  1860.  Number 
of  pupils,  girls  5,  boys  4.     Total,  9. 

The  Legislature  of  California,  at  its  last  ses- 
sion, made  an  appropriation  of  $10,000,  for  a 
building  to  be  erected  in  San  Francisco,  for  the 
education  and  maintenance  of  the  Deaf-Mute  and 
Blind  Children  of  the  State.  The  building  will 
be  erected  as  soon  as  possible  ;  but  at  present, 
the  Institution  is  under  the  charge  and  control 
of  the  Lady  Managers,  who  are  now  ready  to 
receive    all    children    of  this  unfortunate    class; 


APPENDIX. 


441 


and  as  the  enterprise  reliea  entirely  upon  the 
exertions  oi   the    Ladies  for  Its  support,   it  is 

hoped  that  all  will  lake  an  interest  in  it.     Among 

charitable  Institutions  so  liberally  sus- 
tained by  the  wealthy  and  benevolent,  none  is 
more  worthy  of  support  than  this.  The 
will  be  free  to  all;  yet  it  is  expected  of  Parents 
ami  Guardiansoi  Children,  who  have  theability, 
to  pay  $300  per  annum,  and  of  those  in  more 
moderate    eireumstauees,    what  they  are  Willing, 

or  conveniently  can. 

The  Managers  propose  to  receive   all  of  suita- 

ommence  their  education,  and  it  is 

considered  better  to  send  the  Deaf-Mutes  young, 
say  5  years  old,  as  it  is  essential  they  should 
learn  the  Sign  Language  correctly  at  the  com- 
mencement. 

Officers — President.    Mrs.  P.  B.   Clarke;  Vice

MAX  GENERAL  BENEVOLENT  SO- 
CIETY of  San  Francisco,  styled  in  German,  Die 
'  rstuetzwig's  Oes> 

32 


is  one  of  the  largest  and  mosl  aritable 

urns  in  the  State.      It    was  organised   on 
the  7th  January,  is.")  l.  with  105  member 

has  rapidly  increased,  until  now  it  numbers  1,030 
members,  of  whom  about  two-thirds  reside  in 
this  city,  and  one-third  in  the  interior.  Duly 
Germans  and  persons  speaking  German  are  ad- 
mitted to  membership.  The  chief  purpose  of  the 
association  is  mutual  assistance  in  ease  of  sick- 
id  when  sick,  every  member  has  a  right 
t"  demand  support  and  medical  attendance  from 
the  Society.      The  Society  has  a  second  purpose, 

of  doing  charity  to  Germans  not  members  of  the 
ion,  ami  especit  lly  toG  rman  immigrants 

newly  arrived.  The  Society  has  a  Hospital,  built 
ot  brick,  two  stories  high,  with  a  basement  50 
feet  by  To  mi  the  ground,  fitted  up  with 
sulphur,  hot  and  cold  water  and  shower  baths, 
and  oilier  conveniences  for  the  treatment  ot'  the 
sick.  The  wards  are  smaller  than  in  any  other 
Hospital  in  the  city,  se>  thai  not  many  patients 
are  put  together  in  a  room.  The  Hospital  lot  is 
on  Brannan  street,  near  Third,  and  is  131  feet 
wide  by  275  long,  the  whole  surrounded  by  a 
high  fence  and  cultivated  in  a  fine  garden,  part 
planted  with  ornamental  flowers  and  shrubs,  and 
part  with  kitchen  vegetables.  The  water  forthe 
Hospital  and  garden  is  supplied  by  an  artesian 
well  and  windmill  The  property  of  the  Si 
including  the  lot  and  Hospital  building,  is  worth 
about  $24,000,  and  the  debts  amount  to  about 
$7,000.  The  revenue  of  the  Society  amounts  to 
$16,000  or  $17,000  a  year,  derived  chiefly  from 
a  monthly  assessment  of  $1  levied  on  every 
member.     The  Hospital  5,000   a  year. 

During  1859  there  were  214 patients  in  the  Hos- 
pital. During  the  last  live  years,  1>7'.>  persons, 
non-members  of  the  Association,  were  received 
in  the  Hospital  out  of  pure  charity,  ami  main- 
tained by  the  Association  during  7,4  11  sick  days 
in  all.  at  an  expense  of  $14,860.  The  Society 
has  as.  paid  servants,  a  Superintendent,  an 
apothecary,  a  gardener,  a  cook  and  three  waiters, . 
and  one  unpaid  employment  agent.  The  present 
1 9  of  the  society  are  : 

Officers — President.  0.  F.  Mebius  ;  Vice  Presi- 
dent. L.  Jacoby ;  Second  Vice  President,  Dr.  F. 
YV.  Wedekind;  Recording  Secretary,  M.  Mend- 
heim;  Financial  Secretary,  H.  Michels;  Treasu- 
rer, H.  Nielsen;  Directors,  J.  X.  Rausch,  M. 
Waterman.  W.  A.  Krahe,  J.  C.  Meussdorffer,  F. 
Mutzenbecher,  J.  S.  Ilittell  and  K.  Feuerstein; 
Physicians,  Drs.  Alers,  Loehr,  Preeht  and  Re- 
urger. 

The  Superintendent,  L.  Lubbersmeier,  may  be 
found  at  the  Hospital,  and  to  him  application 
should  be  made  for  charitable  relief,  or  acta 
into  the  Society  or  Hospital.  J.  Lorber,  mer- 
chant-clothier, behind  the  City  Hall,  is  gratuitous 
agent  for  the  Society,  to  furnish  employment  and 
servants  to  applicants,  without  charge. 

HIBERNIAN  SOCIETY.— This  Society  is 
composed  of  citizens  of  Irish  birth,  aud  numbers 
50  members;  organized  February  3d,  1852.  The 
object  of  the  organization  is  to  perpetuate  geue- 
rosiiy,  by  extending  relief  to  Irish  emigrants.

cieta  Italianadi  Mutua  Beneficenza). — Organized 
October  IT.  1858.  This  is  a  mutual  relief  socie- 
ty, established  fur  the  purpose  of  affording  aasist- 
indigent  sick  Italians.  By  an  arrange- 
ment with  the  French  Benevolent  Society,  ample 
accommodation  is  provided  at  the  hospital  of  that 
excellent  institution  to  carry  out  the  praisewor- 
thy objects  ofthe  association  Office  123  Jackson.

LADIES1  PROTECTION  AND  RELIEF  SO- 
CIETY.— EstabUshed  Aug.  4th.  1853.  duly  in- 
corporated according  to  law,  Aug.  11th  1857. 
Home  and  office,  south  side  of  Tehama,  between 
First  and  Second  streets.  The  object  of  this  So- 
le to  render  protection  and  assistance  to 
strangers,  to  sick  and  dependent  women  and 
children.  This  Society  has  under  its  supervision 
a  Home,  where  the  poor  are  sheltered,  and  their 
wants  relieved. 

s — President,    Mrs.    Nathaniel    Gray ;

LADIES'  SEA  MENS  FRIEND  SO- 
CIETY.—Organized  March  26,  1856.  The  ob- 
ject of  the  Society  is  to  establish  a  boarding 
house  for  seamen,  where  they  may  tind  a  home 
and  protection,  and  be  surrounded  with  influ- 
ences which  shall  tend  to  their  moral  and  intel- 
lectual improvement;  and  to  supply  the  desti- 
tute with  clothing.  The  building  occupied  by 
.the  Society  is  located  on  Front  Street  between 
Pacific  and  Broadway,  and  it  is  well  adapted  to 
the  benevolent  objects  of  the  Society. 

Officers — First  Directress.  Mrs.  A.  E.  A.  Hol- 
brook;  Second  Directress,  Mrs.  M.  N.  Thurs- 
ton: Corresponding  Secretary.  Mrs.  E.  Peck; 
Recording  Secretary.  Mrs.  H  Rowell;  Treasu- 
rer, Mrs.  C.  E.  Cogswell.

ST.  JOSEPH'S  BENEVOLENT  SOCIETY, 
(1!.  C.)— Established  I860!  The  objects  of  this 
Society  axe  to  extend  assistance  to  each  other  in 
thf  time  df  sickness  by  corpora]  aid  and  spiritual 
consolation;  for  providing  their  deceased  breth- 
ren with  a  decent  ami  christian  interment  iii  ac- 
cordance with  their  Holy  Faith;  for  the  relief 
of  the  families  tiny  may  leave  after  them;  as 
also,  for  stimulating  each  other  to  a  more  con- 
stant observance  of  the  duties  of  religion  and 
the  general  promotion  of  moral  and  intellectual 
improvement.      Officers  not  yet  elected.

SCHEDULE  II. — Rates  of  Storage  on  Merchandise. 
Measurement  goods,  per  month,  $1  00  per  ton  of  forty 

cubic  feet;  heavy  ditto,  si  00  per  ton  Of  2,000  lbs:  or,  in 
either  case,  tlie  amount  actually  paid.     The  consignees  to 

have  the  option  of  charging  by  weight  or  measurement. 
A  fraction  of  a  month  to  be  charged  as  a  month. 

Resolutions  — Ooricerning  delivery  of  Merchandise,  pay- 
ment affreight,  etc. 

When  no  express  stipulations  exist  per  bill  of  lading, 
i i-  are  to  be  considered  as  deliverable  on  shore. 

Freight  on  all  goods  to  be  paid,  or  secured  to  the  satis- 
faction of  the  captain  or  consignee  of  the  vessel,  prior  to 
the  delivery  of  goods. 

Alter    the   delivery   to   the    purchaser   of  merchandise 

sold,  no  claims  for  damage,  deficiency  or  other  cause, 
shall  be  admissible,  unless  made  within  three  days,  and 

li"  smli  claims  shall  be  admissible  after  goods  sold  and 
delivered  have  "iieo  left  the  city. 

When  foreign  bills  of  lading  do  not  expressly  stipulate 

the  payment  of  freight  in  a  specific  coin,  foreign  currency 
shall  be  reckoned  according  to  the  United  states  value 
thereof,  and  payment  may  he  made  in  any  legal  tender  of 
the  United  Stale-. 

Where  foreign  bills  of  lading  expressly  stipulate  that 
the  freight  shall  be  paid  in  a  specific  coin,  then  the  same 
must  be  procured,  if  required,  or  Its  equivalent  given  — 
the  rate  to  be  determined  by  the  current  value  at  the 
time  in  San  Francisco. 

For  tare  on  china  sugar,  4  lbs  is  to  be  allowed  for  each 
mat  containing  4  pockets  of  about  26  lbs  each. 

All  other  rates  of  tare  are  to  he  allowed  as  by  custom 
in  New  York,  except  w  hen  otherwise  provided.

ganized for  social  and  protective  purposes.

dent, N".  Leisner;  Secretary,  Thomas  Mcran ;

SOCIETY  OF  CALIFORNIA  PIONEERS.,- 
Rooms,  Pioneer  Hall.  X  Bide  Washingto 
Kearny.    Organized  in  August,  1850.     Officers — 
For  the  year  commencing  July  7th,  L859.    Presi- 
dent. Philip  A.  Roach;  Vice  Presidents,  Willard 

B.  Farwell,  of  San  Francisco;  Otis  V.Saw 

San  Francisco;  James  Lick,  of  Santa  Clara:  Ceo. 

C.  Yount.  of  Napa;  Joseph  W.  Winans,  of  Sacra- 
mento; .  William  R.  Whi 

urer,  John  11.  Turner:  Directors,  John  S.  Ellis, 
II.  P.  Williams.  J.  H.  Stearns.  J,  E.  Lawrence, 
John  Benson.  J.  II.  Widber,  and  George  II. 
Tay.     The  President,  Secretary  and  Tri 

members  of  the  Board  of  Directors, 
and  Trustees  of  the  Society.  The  expressed 
objects  of  the  Society  are  to  colled  and  pre- 
serve information  connected  with  the  early  set- 
tlement and  subsequent  conquest  of  the  country, 
and  to  perpetuate  the  memory  of  those  whose 
sagacity,  energy  and  enterprise  induced  them 
in  the  wilderness  and  become  the  found- 
ers Of  a  new  State.  All  who  were  in  I 
nia  prior  to  the  first  day  of  January.  1850,  are 
eligible  to  membership.  Any  who  may  have 
rendered  distinguished  or  im]  vices  to 

the  Society,  the  State,  or  the  United  States,  may 


be  admitted  as  honorary  members.     At  this  date 

the  roll  of  the  Society  embraces  the  names  of  991 
members.  Regular  meetings  of  the  Society  take 
place  on  the  first  Monday  of  each  month.  Annual 
election  of  officers  on  the  seventh  day  of  July. 
Annual  celebration  on  September  9th.  The 
Society  are  possessed  of  an  excellent  Library, 
and  are  about  to  erect  a  building  on  the  lot  on 
Mont 'joinery  street,  recently  donated  to  them  by 
one  of  their  members,  James  Lick,  Ksq.

ASSOCIATION.  —  Rooms,  Pacific  Street,  near 
a.  Organized  October,  1854;. re-organized 
October.  1855.  Number  of  members,  138.  Num- 
ber of  volumes  in  the  library.  1,200,  exclusive  of

o'clock  A.  M.  to  12  M.  and  from  2  to  11  P.  M.

M  E(  'II AXI CS'  IXSTTT  CT  E.  —  Organized 
March  29.  1856..  Rooms.  82 Montgomery  street. 
second  floor.  The  objects  of  the  Institute  are 
the  establishment  of  a  library,  reading-room,  col- 
lection of  a  cabinet,  scientific  apparatus,  works 
of  art.  and  other  literary  and  scientific  purposes. 
The  Society  has  a  reading-room  well  supplied 
with  the  leading  scientific  and  literary  periodi- 
cals of  the  day.  and  a  valuable  library  containing 
over  4,500  volumes.  During  the  year  1858,  this 
Institute  presented  to  the  attention  of  the  people 
of  California  their  second  annual  exhibition  of 
mechanical  arts,  which  was  attended  with  the 
omplete  success.  The  Institute  are  now 
making  the  most  extensive  preparations  for  then- 
third  annual  exhibition,  to  be  held  in  September 
next.  'I'lie  building  recently  erected  in  this  city 
for  the  purpose,  is  one  of  the  most  commi 
in  the  Union,  and  from  the  interest  man 
throughout  the  State,  to  promote  the  praise- 
worthy exertions  of  the  Comnhtee  having  the 
matter  in  charge,  there  is  scarcely  a  doubt  but 
that  their  efforts  will  meet  with  the  most  com- 
plete si.

Gardner  Elliot,  Benjamin  Dore,  Paul  Torquet, 
Henry  L.  King,  J.  P.  Buckley.  James  A.  Sperry.

MERCANTILE  LIBRARY  ASSOCIATION.— 

tile  Library  Buildings,  XK  corner  Mont- 
gomery and  Bush.  Organized  January  24th, 
is."):;,  by  the  election  ofD.  8.  Turner,  President; 
Joshua  P.  Haven.  Vice  President;  C.  E.Bowers, 
Treasurer;  YV.  II.  Stevens,  Recording  Secretary; 
Dr.  Eenry  Gibbons,  Corresponding  Secretary; 
;m.  1  Messrs.  E.  I'.  Flint.  E.  1':.  Dunbar,  D.  II. 
Haskell  and  J.  B.  Crockett,  Directo 

6,  I860.— President,  William  II. 
Stevens;  Vice  President,  William  R.  Garrison; 
Treasurer,  J.  G.  Kellogg;  Corresponding 
tary,  K.  B.  Swain:  Recording  Secretary,  Edward 
Hunt ;  Directors,  Charles  Wblcott  Brooks,  Frank 
Baker,  D.  P.  Belknap.  Win.  Norris,  James  W.  J. 

i.  Johu  Shaw,  H.  C.  Macy,  ('has.  R,  Bond, 
Thomas  Bennett. 

The  Mercantile  Library  Association   hi 

larefully  and  ably  conducted,  and  most 
generously  sustained  by  the  citizens  of  San  Fran- 

and  from  the  progress  it  has  made  during 
the  past  few  years,  it  must  soon  take  rank  with 
its  kindred  institutions  in  the  Eastern  States. 
The  library  of  the  association  is  the  second  in  the 

State,  numbering  over  12,000  volumes  of  works 

differenl   departments  of  literature.     Con- 
with  the  library  is  a  valuable  and  extensive 

ion  of  works  of  reference,  3,500  volumes  iu 
extent,  which  is  open  to  the  inspection  of  visitors 
and  the  public  in  general.  The  amount  expended 
for  books,  etc..  for  increase  of  library,  during  the 
last  fiscal  year,  was  $2,500;  increase  of  library 
<luring  same  period.  1,600  volumes ;  incr 
library  from  January  1855,  to  May  1860,  8,600 
volumes.  The  new  rooms  of  the  Association  are 
commodious  ami  conveniently  arranged,  and  are 
well  adapted  to  meet  the  growing  importance 
of  the  institution.  A  well  selected  assortment 
of  the  leading  newspapers  and  periodicals  of 
the  United  States  and  Europe,  are  contained 
therein ;  and  in  addition  thereto,  a  cabinet  of  spe- 
cimens of  mineralogy  and  the  natural  history  of 
te,  and  a  numerous  and  valuable  collection 
of  paintings,  engravings,  etc.  Number  of  mem- 
bers. 1,800;  average  number  of  volumes  taken 
out  monthly,  2,800.  The  terms  of  admission  to 
the  rooms  and  library  are  $2  initiation  fee.  ami 
SI  per  month,  payable  quarterly.  The  influence 
of  an  institution  of  this  character,  properly  di- 
rected, cannot  be  estimated;  and  it  can  scarcely 
be  doubted  that  the  esprit  du  corps  of  the  mer- 
cantile community  of  this  city  will  sustain  and 
enlarge  this  association,  by  confiding  its  manage- 
ment to  energetic  and  Talented  men,  and  by 
liberally  contributing  to  its  Bupp

"  ST.  MARYS  LIBRARY  ASSOCIATION.— 
Organized  1855.  Rooms,  basement  St.  Mary's 
Cathedral  This  Association  has  a  valuable  and 
well  selected  library  of  about  800  volumes,  the 
advantages  of  which  may  be  secured  by  those 
desirous  of  becoming  members,  on  payment  of 
the  entrance  fee  of  50  cents,  and  a  monthly  sub- 
scription of  25  cents.  There  is  attached  to  this 
Library,  a  valuable  collection  of  Manuscript  Let- 
ters of  the  old  Spanish  Missionaries,  relating  to 
the  early  history  of  the  Missions  of  Upper  and 
Lower  California,  dating  from  the  middle  of  the 
last  century.  The  Library  room  is  open  every 
Sunday  afternoon  for  the  reception  of  visitors 
and  persons  desirous  of  becoming  members,  and 
on  Thursday  evenings.  Regular  monthly  meet- 
ings first  Monday  of  each  month. 

Officers — Fresident.  JohnO'Kane:  Vice  Presi- 
dent. J.  Aherne ;  Recording  Secretary.  P.  0. 
Barry:  Corresponding  Secretary.  John  P.  Car- 
roll ;  Treasurer,  Hugh  Murray ;  Librarian,  Wm. 
Ash. 


Social.

1 1  A  RMI  >NIC  SOCIETY.— Organized  January, 
1867. — This  is  a  very  flourishing,  and  for  its  age, 

one  of  the  most   successful   musical   associations 

in  the  State.  It  is  composed  principally  of  ama- 
teurs, and  from  the  efforts  already  made  by  its 
enterprising  members,  it  must  soon  rank  with  the 
first  musical  societies  of  the  country.  Number 
of  members,  .s">.  Officers — President,  David  S. 
Turner;  Vice  President,  G.  "W".  Bell:  Set  retary, 
Robert  George;  Treasurer,  H.  Sehmiedell;  Li- 
brarian, Theo.  E.  Smith;  Trustees,  J.  II.  Tit- 
comb,  J.  W.  J.  Pierson,  Geo.  M.  Scudder,  Wm. 
Horton,  J.  M  Shattuck.

Indep't  Order  of  Knighthood. 

This  Charitable  and  Benevolent  institution  is 
of  purely  California  origin,  being  first  organized 
at  1'olso'm.  October  16th,  1858. 

There  is  in  this  State  at  the  present  time  a 
Grand  Supreme  Council  of  the  United  States,  a 
Grand  Camp  of  the  State  of  California,  and  :::'. 
Subordinate  Camps,  all  in  good  flourishing  con- 
dition.

baugh,  M,  W.  G.

SAX  FRANCISCO  STEAM  SUGAR  RE- 
FINING  CO. — Comer  Harrison  and  Price.  This 
establishment  is  owned  by  an  incorporated  com- 
pany, consisting  of  Xew  York  and  San  Fran- 
cisco merchants.  The  building  is  To  feet  in 
front  by  1122  feet  in  depth,  and.  including  the 
stories  in  hight.  The  capacity  of 
the  works  is  equal  to  the  manufacture  of  400 
tons  Of  refined  sugar  and  20,000  gallons  of  syrup 
per  month.  On  tiic  premises  are  a  steam-power 
cooperage  shop,  20  feet  wide  by  100  feet  in 
depth,  for  the  manufacture  of  kegs  and  barrels; 
a  bone-black  manufactory,  and  two  ai 
wells,  which  discharge  70,000  gallons  per  day, 
5  feet  above  the  surface  of  the  ground.  The 
neighboring  markets  Of  the  Sandwich  Islands, 
Manila,  Batavia  and  China,  furnish  sup; 
raw  sugar.     Offio  rme.

and  the  operations  of  the  company,  sec  General 

Review.

WELLS,  FARGO  &  CO.— This  is  a  joint 
stock  company,  with  a  capital  of  $600,000. 
Principal  office,  in  New  York,  at  84  Broadway. 
President,  D.  N.  Barney ;  Treasurer,  C.  F.  La- 
tham ;  General  Agent,  Louis  McLane,  Jr. ;  Su- 
perintendent Express  and  Banking  Departments, 
Samuel  Knight.  Principal  office  in  California, 
in  Parrott's  Building,  cor  Montgomery  and  Cali- 
fornia streets.  This  company  has  branch  ex- 
press offices  in  all  the  principal  cities  and  towns 
in  California  and  Oregon,  and  banking  offices  at 
Sacramento  and  Stockton,  Cal.,  Portland,  Oregon, 
and  Victoria,  V.  I.,  connecting  in  their  express 
business  with  all  the  principal  express  companies 
in  the  Atlantic  States  and  Europe.  Established 
branch  in  California,  July  13,  1852. 

WHARF  CONVENTION— Representing  the 
following  wharves,  viz.:  Market,  Central,  Clay, 
Washington,  Jackson,  and  Vallejo,  city  wharves, 
the  leases  of  which  expire  in  1863,  with  the  ex- 
ception of  Central,  which  is  perpetual,  and  Green- 
wich, Lombard  and  North  Point,  private 
wharves,  on  private  property.  President,  Robert 
Roxby;  Treasurer,  H.  S.  Gates;  Secretary,  R. 
B.  Macy ;  General  Wharfinger,  L.  B.  Edwards. 
Office,  134  Clay. 


Telegraph  Lines. 

CALIFORNIA  STATE  TELEGRAPH.— 
Office  hours  from  8  o'clock,  A.  M.  to  9  o'clock, 
P.  M.  This  line  extends  to  the  following  inte- 
rior towns  and  mining  camps,  viz. :  San  Fran- 
cisco, Stockton,  Sacramento,  Marysville,  Placer- 
ville,  Timbuctoo,  Smartsville,  Grass  Valley, 
Nevada,  Oroville,  Chico,  Tehama,  Shasta,  Trinity 
Centre,  Yreka,  Gilroy,  Visalia,  Los  Angeles,  San 
Jose  Warm  Springs,  Folsom,  El  Dorado,  Dia- 
mond Springs,  Strawberry  Valley,  Genoa,  Carson 
City,  Virginia  City,  Miller's  Station,  Red  Bluffs, 
Ilorsetown,  Weaverville,  Callahan's  Ranch,  San 
Juan  South,  Watsonville,  Fresno — connect  at 
San  Jose  with  the  Pacific  and  Atlantic  line,  at 
Placerville  with  the  Placerville  and  St.  Joseph 
Overland  Telegraph,  and  at  Marysville  with  the 
Northern  California  Telegraph.  Office:  162 
Montgomery. 

ALTA  CALIFORNIA  TELEGRAPH  COM- 
PAQ V.— Office  hours  from  8  A.  M.  to  9  P.  M. 
Sundays  9  to  11  A.  M.  This  line  extends  to  the 
following  interior  towns  and  precincts:  Santa 
Clara,  San  Jose,  San  Leandro,  Martinez,  Benicia,

Vallejo,  Napa,  Suisun,  Sacramento,  Placerville,

line  extends  from  San  Jose  to  Los  Angeles,

Hospitals,  etc. 

BRITISH  HOSPITAL.— This  institution  baa 
been  discontinued,  and  an  arrangement  made 
with  the  city  to  provide  fur  the  indigent  sick  of 
the  British  association. 

COUNTY   HOSPITAL— SW  corner  Francisco 

and  Stockton.  Resident  Physician,  Charles  H. 
Raymond,  M.  I>. ;  Visiting  Surgeon,  V.  A.  Bol- 
man,  M.  D.;  Visiting  Physician,  S.  P.  (Jerry,  M. 
D. ;  Joseph  B.  Loud,  Contractor  for  Diet,  etc. 
Average  number  of  patients,  L63;  daily  admis- 
3.     Deaths  about  10  per  cent,  per  annum. 

FRENCH   HOSPITAL.—  Sustained  by  the 

French  Benevolent  Society;   Simmons  and  Fifth. 
(See  Benevolent  Associations.) 

GERMAN  HOSPITAL.  —  Sustained  by  the 
German  Benevolent  Society;  Brannan  and  Third. 
(See  Benevolent  Associations.) 

ITALIAN  HOSPITAL.  — Sustained  by  the 
Italian  Mutual  Benevolent  Society.  (See  Benevo- 
lent Associations.) 

HOSPITAL  OF  THE  SISTERS  OF  MERCT. 
— (Late  State  Marine  Hospital.)  Nos.  324  and 
326  Stockton  Street,  between  Broadway  and 
Vallejo  streets.  Attending  Physicians,  Drs.  A. 
J.  Bowie  and  J.  P.  Whitney ;  Apothecary,  J.  H. 
Clarke:  Steward,  J.  Kelly.  The  religious  sister- 
hood attend  the  patients  in  person  ;  they  number 
20,  who  are  distributed  about  the  various  duties 
of  the  hospital,  some  as  nurses,  others  attending 
the  departments  of  cooking,  washing,  etc.  Ave- 
rage number  of  patients,  35  per  month;  deaths, 
per  month,  1. 

UNITED  STATES  MARINE  HOSPITAL.— 
Rincon  Point,  between  Main  and  Spear.  Organ- 
ized 16th  March,  1852.  Original  officers — D. 
Jamison,  Surgeon ;  Rev.  0.  Clark,  Superintend- 
ent; R.  McMillan,  Surgeon;  G.  W.  Beach, 
Apothecary.  Building  erected  November,  1853. 
Officers  —  Surgeon  and  Resident  Physician, 
Richard  T.  Maxwell ;  Assistant  Surgeon,  John 
Y.  Lind  ;  Steward,  M.  A.  Sullivan ;  Apothecary, 
F.  T.  Maynard;  Matron,  Catharine  Sullivan.  Daily 
admissions,  5 ;  deaths  per  month,  5 ;  average 
number  of  patients,  169. 

PACIFIC  CLINICAL  INFIRMARY.  —  Dr. 
Cooper  ;  Mission  between  Second  and  Third. 
In  this  institution  are  treated  patients  who  suffer 
from  diseases  of  the  eye,  ear,  and  general  surgical 
affections.  Surgeon,  Professor  E.  S.  Cooper. 
M.  D. 

INFIRMARY— Diseases  of  the  ear  treated. 
Dr.  John  B.  Pilkington,  proprietor.  NE  corner 
Montgomery  and  California. 


Cemeteries. 

CEMETERY,  JEWISH— Near  Mission  Do- 
lores. 

CEMETERY,  LONE  MOUNTAIN.— 2  J  miles 
W  from  Montgomery,  and  directly  opposite  Cali- 


fornia st.;  road  mostly  traveled  leads  from  Hush. 
metery  was  dedicated  in  June,  1854,  and 
is  the  property  of  private  individuals,  wb< 
sign  i-  to  incorporate  soon.  It  contains  an  area 
of  160  acres.  The  grounds  are  beautifully  un- 
dulating, with  avenues  leading  through  the  ra- 
vines, and  then  gradually  rising  to  an  eminence, 
from  which  you  have  a  commanding  view  of  the 
surrounding  country.  On  the  south,  three- 
eighths  of  a  mile  distant,  stands  the  celebrated 
Lone  Mountain,  a  lofty  conical  shaped  hill,  from 
which  the  cemetery  derives  its  name.  ( >n  the 
east  lies  the  city  and  the  bay,  with  the  villages 
of  Oakland,  Alameda  and  Clinton,  and  in  the 
distance  Mount  Diablo.  On  the  north  may  be 
seen  the  Bay  of  San  Pablo,  Angel's  and  Alea- 
traces  Islands,  Saucelito  Bay  and  village,  and  tho 
entrance  to  the  Golden  Gate.  On  the  west  in 
the  distance,  you  have  the  Farallon  Islands  and 
the  Pacific  Ocean,  the  roar  of  whose  waves  is 
sounding  a  continual  requiem  as  if  to  soothe  tho 
spirits  of  the  dead.  The  shrubbery  is  mostly 
evergreen,  containing  more  than  twenty  different 
kinds  of  flowering  shrubs.  About  4,500  inter- 
ments have  already  been  made  within  the  in- 
closure,  and  the  improvements  now  made  and 
others  designed,  with  its  natural  beauties,  bid 
fair  to  make  this  rival  any  of  the  rural  cemeteries 
of  the  Atlantic  States. 

Officers — Trustees,  David  S.  Turner  and  John 
Ferry.  Jr.;  Treasurer,  W.  F.  Herrick;  Superin- 
tendent, Joseph  H.  Atkinson.  On  the  grounds 
is  erected  a  receptacle  vault  capable  of  contain- 
ing 50  bodies — also,  a  chapel.  First  interment, 
June  28,  1854.  Monthly  average  of  interments 
at  this  cemetery,  80.     Office,  167  Clay. 

CEMETERY,  ROMAN  CATHOLIC— Mis- 
sion Dolores,  under  charge  of  the  church. 

CEMETERY,  YERBA  BUENA— Is  bounded 
SE  by  Market,  N  by  McAllister  and  W  by 
Larkin.

461 


BOINTUS   YEAR 


ESTABLISHED,     1836. 

Capital,  £1,259,760  sterling 

Accumulated  Premium  Fund  upwards  of  £350,000. 

OFFICE  IN  LONDON,  No.  1  MOORGATE  STREET. 


The  next  investigation  for  the  purpose  of  declaring  a  Bonus  to 
the  Policy-holders,  will  take  place  on  the  31st  January,  1861,  and 
all  Policies  in  the  Participating  Class,  effected  prior  to  that  date, 
will  share  in  the  profits  then  to  be  divided.  The  whole  of  the 
profits  of  this  Branch  are  divisible,  in  terms  of  the  Act  of  Incor- 
poration, among  the  Insured. 

The  last  Bonus  declared  by  the  Company  was  at  the  rate  of 
£1.70  6d.  per  cent,  per  annum  on  the  amount  insured,  a  return 
which,  when  its  very  moderate  scale  of  premiums  is  considered, 
has  rarely  been  exceeded  by  any  other  office. 

As  an  illustration  of  the  additions  already  made  to  Policies,  it 
will  be  sufficient  to  state  that  a  Policy  for  .£1000,  taken  out  in 
1836,  has  been  increased  by  successive  Bonus  additions  to  the  sum 
of  £1351  Is.  lOd.  All  Policies  are  guaranteed  by  a  subscribed 
Capital  of  upwards  of  One  Million  Sterling,  an  accumulated  and 
invested  premium  fund  of  over  £350,000,  and  the  unlimited 
responsibility  of  upwards  seven  hundred  shareholders. 

For  Prospectuses,  Tables  of  Rates,  and  Forms  of  Proposals,  apply  to 

WM.  LANE  BOOKER,  Agent, 

126  California  St.,  San  Francisco.

ROYAL  INSURANCE  CO. 


CAPITAL,  TEN  MILLIONS  OF  DOLLARS. 

The  undersigned,  Agents  iu  California  for  the  above  named  Company,  are  prepared 
to  issue  Policies,  Insuring  Brick  Buildings,  or  Merchandise  stored  therein,  House- 
hold Furniture,  etc.,  and  are  authorized  to  settle  all  losses  here. 

The  amount  of  the  Capital  of  this  Company,  viz.,  Ten  Millions  of  Dollars,  which 
would  be  immediately  available  to  meet  any  unforeseen  calamity,  the  well-known 
character  of  its  Directors,  the  high  respectability  of  its  proprietors,  and  the  standing 
which  it  takes  among  the  large  Insurance  Establishments,  enable  it  to  rank  with  the 
most  eligible  offices  now  in  existence,  either  in  Europe  or  America,  with  respect  to 
the  advantages  offered  to  the  Public. 

This  Company  will  ever  distinguish  itself  by  Promptness  in  the  Settlement-  of

469 


ESTABLISHED,    1850. 


VULCAN  IRON  WORKS  CO. 

FIRST  STREET,  NEAR  GAS  WORKS. 

Iron  Founders  and  Steam  Ens inc  Builders. 


The  Machine  Shop  possesses  the  greatest  number  and  the  largest  dimensions  of 
Tools  in  the  State.  They  have  Lathes  to  turn  nine  feet  in  diameter  and  thirty  feet 
long.  Their  other  facilities  for  executing  work  rapidly  and  efficiently  are  unsurpassed. 
Upwards  of  100  StGam  Engines  made  at  their  own  Works,  are  now  running 
in  this  State  and  Oregon,  in  Steamboats,  Quartz  Mills,  Saw  and  Flouring  Mills. 

Their  Boiler  Works  have  turned  out  upwards  of  300  Steam  Boilers 

of  all  kinds. 

Quartz  Mills,  Flour  Mills,  Hydraulic  and  other  Presses,  Hoisting  Machines,  Gear- 
ing, Pullies,  Gudgeons,  Boxes  and  Hangers,  etc.,  in  great  variety  ;  Quartz  Stampers, 
Shoes  and  Dies,  warranted  to  be  made  of  the  very  hardest  and  toughest  Iron. 

Jj^T*  A  published  list  of  the  Patterns  of  these  Works  will  be  sent  upon  application. 

RIGHT   TO  MANUFACTURE 

Tyler's  Patent  Scroll  Water  Wheel, 

The  cheapest,  most  portable  and  effective  Machine  ever  invented, 

for  the  application  of  water  as  motive  power.     These  Wheels  are  entirely  made  of 

iron,  simple  and  not  liable  to  get  out  of  order.     Circulars  containing 

tables  of  power  and  velocity,  will  be  sent  on  application.

UNION  IRON  WORKS, 

(Established  in  1849.) 

North-East  Corner  of  First  and  Mission  Streets, 


The  above  Establishment  has  been  iu  successful  operation  for  the  last  eleven 
years,  during  which  time  new  aud  extensive  Buildings  have  been  erected,  and  the 
latest  improvements  added  to  the  Works,  which  enable  the  undersigned  to  supply 
all  demands  for 


of  every  description,  on  the  shortest  notice,  and  finished  in  a  style 
of  workmanship  that  cannot  be  surpassed. 

STEAM  ENGINES  BUILT  &  REPAIRED. 

QUARTZ  MILLS,  SAW  MILLS,  THRESHING  MACHINES,  HORSE  POWERS, 

GRIST  MILLS,  GEARING,  MALT  ROLLERS,  and  ALL  KINDS  of  MILL 

WORK,  STEAMBOAT  REPAIRING,  BLACKSMITHING,  ETC. 

Besides  the  extensive  assortment  of  MACHINERY  PATTERNS,  attention 

is  called  to  the  new  and  beautiful  designs  for 

BUILDING  CASTINGS,  IRON  FRONTS  and  COLUMNS  for  STORES, 

Railings  for  Balconies  and  Stairs,  Door  and  Window  Sills,  Stair  Cases,  etc.

Manufacturers  of  STEAM  BOILERS,  high  and  low  pressure, 
OF  CYLINDER,  TUBULAR,  OR  FLUE  AND  SHEET   IRON  WORK; 

Of  a  better  quality,  and  at  prices  more  reasonable,  than  any  other  establishment  on 
the  Pacific  Coast. 

Being  practical  Boiler  Makers,  of  long  experience,  confining  our  whole  time  and 
attention  exclusively  to  one  branch  of  business,  and  using  the  best  quality  and  brands 
of  Boiler  and  Sheet  Iron  and  Boiler  Tubes,  enable  us  to  say  to  all  that  are  in  want 
of  any  work  in  the  above  line  to  give  us  a  call,  and  they  shall  find  our  work  to  be  of 
the  best  quality — prices  reasonable,  and  warranted  according  to  order. 

Orders  from  the  country,  by  express  or  otherwise,  with  a  remittance  or  satisfactory 
reference,  will  be  promptly  executed,  and  shipped  as  ordered.  Particular  attention 
paid  to  the  REPAIRING:  OF  STEAM  BOILERS.
